title: Configure Gradle parallelism and Kotlin compiler in `sdk-sync`
body:
## Motivation and Context
Each invocation of `gradlew aws:sdk:assemble` from `sdk-sync` was creating some form of unbounded parallelism that was causing issues with the release process. These changes restrict that a bit more, although something still seems to be doing things in parallel besides `sdk-sync` even after these changes.

title: Only generate `@error` `message` getter when defined in the model

`None` even when the `message` field is not defined in the model.
Granted, in the client this field is _almost always_ there, because the
`AddErrorMessage` model transformer is applied unless the user opts out
in their `smithy-build.json`.

title: remove parallelism from the sync tool
body:
## Motivation and Context
- the build job frequently OOMs

## Description

smithy-build actually utilizes `ForkJoinPool.common()` when executing build projections. Because each service is its own projection, the build internally is _already_ running in parallel. Because of this, running the sync in parallel produces uneccessary memory pressure.

This change:
- removes parallelism
- runs gradle `--no-daemon --info` for better log output


## Testing
- e2e test in sync tool


By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice.

title: Fix release issues by introducing backwards compat into `sdk-versioner`
body:
## Motivation and Context

The `sdk-sync` tool is running into issues during release due to the `sdk-versioner` refactor commit since it is using a Docker build image with the tools precompiled into it. Either the `sdk-versioner` binary is too new and can't code generate the old commits, or it's too old and can't generate the new commits.

This reintroduces the old `sdk-versioner` behavior so that it can succeed against both sets of commits to get a release out.

## Testing
- Verified the arg parsing switching logic works
- The `v1` module is copied unchanged from the original `sdk-versioner` implementation; it should work as it did previously

By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice.

title: Use Vec for route resolution when number of routes <15
body:
## Motivation and Context

* Microbenchmarks [show](https://gist.github.com/daboross/976978d8200caf86e02acb6805961195) that, in the case where the number of elements is less than 20, it's faster to use `Vec::find` over `HashMap::get`
* Closes https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/issues/1326

## Description

* Add `TinyMap` collection, which is a map backed by either `Vec` or `HashMap` depending on the number of entries.
* Replace `HashMap` with  `TinyMap` for `Routes::AwsJson10` and `Routes::AwsJson11`.

title: Refactor `sdk-versioner` to operate off the versions manifest
body:
## Motivation and Context
This is an incremental step towards independent service crate versions for [RFC 12](https://awslabs.github.io/smithy-rs/design/rfcs/rfc0012_independent_crate_versioning.html). This PR refactors the `sdk-versioner` tool used to revise example crate manifests to point to the correct versions of the SDK crates to use the `versions.toml` rather than fixed version numbers.

title: Remove usage of percent_decode_str for decoding query string key-value pairs
body:
## Motivation and Context

* Removing duplicated work done by `percent_encoding::percent_decode_str`
* Prevent eager collection into `Vec` done by `serde_urlencoded::from_str`
* Fixes https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/issues/1231

## Description

* Use `form_urlencoding::parse` over `serde_urlencoded::from_str`, this removes our dependency on `serde_urlencoded`.
* Remove `percent_encoding::percent_decode_str` where possible.
* Contract `generateParsePercentEncodedStrFn` and its children into one function and make it optionally apply percent encoding.
* Add `impl From<std::convert::Infallible> for RequestRejection` to remove codegen branch.

title: Allow @required with @httpPrefixHeaders
body:
The server generates members with @required and @httpPrefixHeaders as if
they were always optional. This commit allows the correct generation with @required.

Closes: #1394 

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here -->

#1394 

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->

## Testing
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->

Same as in #1394 

```
@http(uri: "/requiredHttpPrefixHeaders", method: "GET")
operation RequiredHttpPrefixHeadersOperation {
    input: RequiredHttpPrefixHeadersInputOutput,
    output: RequiredHttpPrefixHeadersInputOutput,
}

structure RequiredHttpPrefixHeadersInputOutput {
    @httpPrefixHeaders("X-Required-")
    @required
    requiredHeaderMap: RequiredHttpPrefixHeadersMap,
}

map RequiredHttpPrefixHeadersMap {
    key: String,
    value: String,
}
```

title: Implement release-aware yank tooling
body:
## Motivation and Context
This is a prerequisite for partial releases and releases with unsynchronized version numbers. Once we start doing those, the new `[release]` section of `versions.toml` (introduced in #1400) will need to be used to yank a release. This PR reworks the existing yank tool to take a release tag or `versions.toml` file path to yank a release rather than the old crate category and repository approach.

title: Correctly generate http response codes
body:
http response codes will be:
* @httpResponseCode if set
* @http's code, if @httpResponseCode is not set
* the default one, if neither of the above are set

@httpResponseCode honors @required and generates code that
doesn't use Option when applied.

Closes: #1229

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here -->

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->

* set http response status to using Option only when not `@required`
* default to `@http`'s code when the status is not set
* default to the builder's default if none is set
* add tests

title: Use md5 implementation of RustCrypto organization
body:
## Motivation and Context

I noticed that the S3 SDK was depending to the `md5` crate which is not part of the `RustCrypto` organization. The `RustCrypto` organization is the de-facto standard of cryptographic primitive implementations in Rust with an active community and already used by `aws-smithy-checksums` for its `sha1` and `sha2` checksums.

## Description

I changed the `md5` crate to the one provided by `RustCrypto`. 

## Testing

No behavior changes to be tested

title: Add release metadata to `versions.toml`
body:
## Motivation and Context
As we start unsynchronizing SDK crate version numbers, we will need to know exactly which crates went out with a given release so that if we need to yank that release, it will actually be possible. This PR revises SDK generation via the `sdk-sync` tool to feed information from the previous release's `versions.toml` into the creation of the next release's `versions.toml` so that this information of which crates actually changed can be retained.

The publisher tool was also modified to read an expected tag from the `versions.toml` file rather than expecting the `aws-config` version number. This will be required also since `aws-config`'s version number won't match the release tag in the future when versions aren't synchronized.

By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice.

title: Unknown enum variants removed from server
body:
The server must have the most up to date variants and the unknown enum
variant should not be used. Clients are generated with it because they
might not have the most recent model and the server might return
an unknown variant to them.

Closes #1187

Signed-off-by: Daniele Ahmed <ahmeddan@amazon.de>

title: Remove individual devs from crate ownership in crates.io
body:
## Motivation and Context
Before this PR, our crates in crates.io have two owners: `awslabs/rust-sdk-owners`, and whoever published the crate for the very first time from the time when crate publication wasn't automated. This PR updates the publisher tool to remove any owners that are not `awslabs/rust-sdk-owners`, which should fix the crate ownership for all crates with the next release.

title: Add excluded headers list in the setting option. for verification …
body:
…signed request

## Motivation and Context
I would like to verify an HTTP request which already been signed with the sigv4, Authorization header.
The header contains:
"SignedHeaders=amz-sdk-invocation-id;amz-sdk-request;amz-sdk-retry;content-length;content-type;host;**user-agent**;x-amz-date;x-amz-target, ..."

To correctly sign the request and verify the signature, I will also need to sign the User-Agent header.

## Description
Add bool flag in the setting option allow_signing_user_agent_header.
The flag is by default false. But can be set to the true outside of the sigv4 crate.
This allows verifying a signed request correctly as the sigv4 is able now to sign also the User-Agent header.

title: Increase max JVM heap size in `gradle.properties`
body:
It's currently defaulting to 512 MiB. I often see this message in my
build logs:

> Daemon will be stopped at the end of the build after running out of JVM memory

I've done some (unscientific) profiling with this setting enabled, and
max heap size can peak at ~600 MiB, so I see no reason to increase it
more than 1024 MiB.

title: Remove axum-core dependency
body:
This change removes the dependency on axum-core and brings in the
relevant resources we are using from that crate.

Issue: #1170

Signed-off-by: Daniele Ahmed <ahmeddan@amazon.de>

## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here -->

Closes https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/issues/1170

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->

The crate axum-core has been removed from the dependencies.
IntoResponse and FromRequest have been kept.
RequestParts has been kept because we need ownership of `body` to consume it in places such as [here](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/blob/ae9a5ed50a4b14296f4ede85b65f5313f1398df3/codegen-server/src/main/kotlin/software/amazon/smithy/rust/codegen/server/smithy/protocols/ServerHttpBoundProtocolGenerator.kt#L588) and have `&mut` requests, but the http crate provides it as a stream and requests are not `Clone`able.

## Testing
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->

`./gradlew :codegen-server-test:test` in the root directory
`cargo test` in `rust-runtime/aws-smithy-http-server`

title: Update `FsBuilder`-based `ByteStreams` to support file offsets
body:
## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here -->
This will help with [aws-sdk-rust#494](https://github.com/awslabs/aws-sdk-rust/issues/494)

## Description
<!--- Describe your changes in detail -->
The `aws_smithy_http::byte_stream::bytestream_util::FsBuilder` has been updated to allow for easier creation of
multi-part requests.

- `FsBuilder::offset` is a new method allowing users to specify an offset to start reading a file from.
- `FsBuilder::file_size` has been reworked into `FsBuilder::length` and is now used to specify the amount of data to read.

With these two methods, it's now simple to create a `ByteStream` that will read a single "chunk" of a file.

## Testing
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->

title: Point example links to example's in current branch so this will work …
body:
## Motivation and Context
<!--- Why is this change required? What problem does it solve? -->
<!--- If it fixes an open issue, please link to the issue here -->

The example links are hard coded to main branch when they could (imo should) be pointed to the examples in the current branch. 

With this change example links points to the current examples folder. This will also allow this to work in other git apps such as gitea.

title: Refactor the `sdk-sync` tool to sync commits in parallel
body:
## Motivation and Context
Each individual smithy-rs commits takes between 3 and 5 minutes to generate code for. This adds up when the number of commits between releases is in the 20s. This PR runs code generation in parallel as much as possible to reduce the total sync time.

title: fix: Silence home directory warning in Lambda Extensions
body:
## Motivation and Context

Similar to [aws-sdk-rust #307](https://github.com/awslabs/aws-sdk-rust/issues/307), suppress the home directory expansion warning when in Lambda. The fix #893 worked for Lambda functions, but not for Extensions.

Related commit: fbb4bc

## Description

This PR follows on to https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/pull/893 which added `LAMBDA_TASK_ROOT` check. When running as a [Lambda Extension](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/lambda/latest/dg/runtimes-extensions-api.html) the environment variable for `LAMBDA_TASK_ROOT` is redacted, so it is not reliable for testing whether you are in Lambda.

To remedy this, I switched the check to use `AWS_LAMBDA_FUNCTION_NAME` so that the check returns correctly for both function handlers and extensions.

## Testing
<!--- Please describe in detail how you tested your changes -->
<!--- Include details of your testing environment, and the tests you ran to -->
<!--- see how your change affects other areas of the code, etc. -->

Ran the full test suite, and validated that this suppresses the warning by rebuilding my local SDK and using it in a Lambda Extension.

To avoid complications with version bumping `aws-config` in the future, the `aws-sdk-sso` and `aws-sdk-sts` types absolutely cannot be exposed in its public API. title: Implement new `sdk-sync` tool
body:
## Motivation and Context
This tool will eventually replace the `smithy-rs-sync` tool and be used in release automation that includes automated model updates. These are the notable differences from `smithy-rs-sync`:
- Operates directly on `aws-sdk-rust/main` rather than on `next`.
- Interactions with other processes have been abstracted behind traits so they can be mocked in tests.
- The previous smithy-rs revision is loaded from `versions.toml` rather than from `.smithyrs-githash`.
- Correct attribution is maintained for example syncing.
- Commits in smithy-rs that produce no SDK changes are no longer included in the sync.
- Model changes are now expected to already be commited to smithy-rs before the tool runs, and are properly incorporated.

## Testing
- Unit tested individual git interactions.
- Thoroughly unit tested with mocked process interactions.
- Created an E2E test that creates fake `aws-sdk-rust`, `smithy-rs`, and `aws-doc-sdk-examples` repositories with test data to verify function against actual git repositories.
- Manually tested against the actual  `aws-sdk-rust`, `smithy-rs`, and `aws-doc-sdk-examples` repositories. Examined the synced commits and verified the model commit is retained in `smithy-rs`.

By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice.

title: Clean generated SDK before assembling a new one
body:
## Motivation and Context
When switching between generating a full SDK and smoketest SDK locally, the smoketest SDK can fail to assemble due to the `smithy-build.json` being inconsistent with the generated crates that are on disk. This breaks the `publisher generate-version-manifest` tool since it relies on `smithy-build.json` to hash to the service models, and at the same time, relies on the file system to discover which service crates exist.

## Testing
- Ran `g -Paws.fullsdk=true aws:sdk:assemble` and then `g aws:sdk:cargoCheck`. Before this PR, this would fail.

title: Generate a `versions.toml` with the SDK
body:
## Motivation and Context
This is prerequisite work for tracking SDK crate versions independently, as described in the [RFC](https://github.com/awslabs/smithy-rs/pull/1194). This PR:
- Introduces a `crate-hasher` tool that builds against Cargo and uses the same code paths that find files for the `cargo package` subcommand, and then SHA-256 hashes those files in a deterministic way
- Introduces a `generate-version-manifest` subcommand in the `publisher` tool which examines the generated SDK and runs the `crate-hasher` against it in order to produce a `versions.toml` file
- Incorporates the new `generate-version-manifest` subcommand into the Gradle `aws:sdk:assemble` task so that the generated SDK now has a `versions.toml` manifest

By submitting this pull request, I confirm that you can use, modify, copy, and redistribute this contribution, under the terms of your choice.

This commit adds an `endpoint_resolver` field to SdkConfig, which flows

title: Simplify CI with composite actions and new image tagging approach
body:
## Motivation and Context
This PR does three things:
1. Refactors CI to use composite actions so that there's less duplication in the workflow yaml files.
2. Switches to a different image tagging approach for the Docker build image: now the git hash of the `tools/` directory is the image tag rather than the commit hash of `HEAD`. This will result in more image reuse if the tools haven't changed, and makes the logic for deciding whether a new image must be built much simpler.
3. When running CI on main, ensures the Docker build image is built and uploaded to ECR before running the CI tests.
